{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3531487,"name":"G3 6740","username":"G3_6740","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/g/3d9bf3/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-02-18T15:42:47.010Z","cooked":"

Hello
My team is looking for new computers to use with solidworks.
We found something with an rtx Quadro 3000.
Does anyone know if that graphics card will run fine? Is there anyone with experience using it?
Thanks

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":16,"updated_at":"2025-02-18T15:42:47.010Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":312,"reads":487,"readers_count":486,"score":1657.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":492174,"topic_slug":"pc-specs-doubt","display_username":"G3 6740","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":29450,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/pc-specs-doubt/492174/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3531510,"name":"Patrick","username":"Patrick3357","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/patrick3357/{size}/169915_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-18T16:00:49.502Z","cooked":"

A professional graphics card is not needed for solidworks. That card should be fine, but I always recommend my students just get a general purpose laptop with a latest generation i5 or i7 CPU (or equivalent). Integrated graphics is fine unless you want to do rendering or some other graphics intensive extra. My last several work and personal laptops as a professional mechanical design engineer have had integrated graphics. That said sometimes without a professional workstation you may run into some weird issue with CAD and you won’t have the tech support to handle it the way you would if you were working for an engineering company. If you/your students already have decent newish laptops just try installing solidworks, it’ll probably be fine.

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":16,"updated_at":"2025-02-18T16:00:49.502Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":478,"readers_count":477,"score":125.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":492174,"topic_slug":"pc-specs-doubt","display_username":"Patrick","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":52597,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Build mentor"},"post_url":"/t/pc-specs-doubt/492174/2","custom_user_title":"Build mentor","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3531518,"name":"ben gates","username":"banjogates","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/banjogates/{size}/251059_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-18T16:05:27.357Z","cooked":"

TL:DR

Yes! The quadro line is Nvidia’s CAD-dedicated line and should be great. My Thinkpad has a quadro T2000 and I’ve had zero issues

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":16,"updated_at":"2025-02-18T16:05:27.357Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":4,"reads":413,"readers_count":412,"score":147.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":492174,"topic_slug":"pc-specs-doubt","display_username":"ben gates","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":38980,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"breh"},"post_url":"/t/pc-specs-doubt/492174/3","custom_user_title":"breh","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3531537,"name":"JamesCH95","username":"JamesCH95","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/jamesch95/{size}/1200_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-18T16:15:36.890Z","cooked":"

Having tested this ad nauseum for my day job:

Core i9, i7, i5 in that order of preference. Disable hyperthreading.

Any GPU, ideally rated for SW. You don’t want integrated graphics, it’ll slog your cpu with more work and noticably slow moderate assemblies and more complex single parts.

The Quadro RTX 3000 is approved in many configurations with SolidWorks. You can go to SolidWorks.com/support/hardware-certification/ for more details.

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":16,"updated_at":"2025-02-18T16:15:36.890Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":364,"readers_count":363,"score":132.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":492174,"topic_slug":"pc-specs-doubt","display_username":"JamesCH95","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"http://SolidWorks.com/support/hardware-certification/","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Hardware Certification | SOLIDWORKS","clicks":9}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":3782,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/pc-specs-doubt/492174/4","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3533414,"name":"Nyx","username":"gellnick","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/gellnick/{size}/172273_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-19T19:47:28.683Z","cooked":"

I haven’t had issues with integrated graphics in the past, but I’ve always been on AMD’s noticeably superior integrated graphics.

Ryzen processors from AMD will certainly provide decent performance in Solidworks as well as Intel processors, and may in fact be faster due to the higher core count and larger cache.

I have a graphics card in my system mostly because I render stuff and play video games on occasion, and it wasn’t that expensive.

And Onshape still likes having system resources to use, but it’s not as power hungry as Solidworks or F360. I remember someone running tests on the same assembly across multiple computers from a Chromebook to a high end workstation and discovering the Chromebook wasn’t really enough for proper cad work. Problem is it needs Internet access, and with how much my Internet doesn’t work, that’s never a guarantee.

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":16,"updated_at":"2025-02-19T19:47:28.683Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":4,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":214,"readers_count":213,"score":57.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":492174,"topic_slug":"pc-specs-doubt","display_username":"Nyx","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":3782,"username":"JamesCH95","name":"JamesCH95","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/jamesch95/{size}/1200_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":29971,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Everything and nothing, all at the same time"},"post_url":"/t/pc-specs-doubt/492174/9","custom_user_title":"Everything and nothing, all at the same time","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3533427,"name":"Chris Bale","username":"cbale2000","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/cbale2000/{size}/2142_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-19T19:58:42.837Z","cooked":"
Patrick3357:

A professional graphics card is not needed for solidworks. That card should be fine, but I always recommend my students just get a general purpose laptop with a latest generation i5 or i7 CPU (or equivalent).

To echo this, the laptop I’ve used for several years has an i7-8750 CPU and a GTX 1060 graphics card and it can handle Autodesk Inventor (comparable requirements to Solidworks) just fine even with large assemblies.

Unless you’ve got a budget to spend or got some crazy good deal on them, Quadro GPUs are probably overkill (and overpriced) for anything you’d need for FIRST purposes. Just about any mid-range gaming laptop (mine only cost like $1000 when I got it new a few years back) with a dedicated GPU will handle pretty much any CAD you can throw at it.

","post_number":10,"post_type":1,"posts_count":16,"updated_at":"2025-02-19T19:58:59.005Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":176,"readers_count":175,"score":40.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":492174,"topic_slug":"pc-specs-doubt","display_username":"Chris Bale","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":6560,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/pc-specs-doubt/492174/10","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3533487,"name":"JamesCH95","username":"JamesCH95","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/jamesch95/{size}/1200_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-19T21:07:53.781Z","cooked":"

Like I mentioned earlier, I have done this topic to death as part of my day job, and I just have to correct a lot of the misinformation in your reply.

gellnick:

I haven’t had issues with integrated graphics in the past, but I’ve always been on AMD’s noticeably superior integrated graphics.

Yes, you can operate SW and other CAD programs on integrated graphics. But if you’re doing anything of significance it sucks real bad. Here is one way I know: SolidWorks RX benchmarks of a T15 Lenovo Laptop with a 12th gen i7 CPU vs a 7 year old Boxx with an 8th gen i7.

image1021×596 105 KB

The T15 i7 12800H CPU has a PassMark single thread score of 3,508 vs the Boxx i7 8700K with a score of 2,748. The Boxx decimates the T15 in Graphics, Processor, and I/O (all the things users directly interface with) because it’s CPU isn’t slagged with doing graphics duty. The T15 has the superior CPU by every on-paper measure, but having to run integrated graphics kills it.

gellnick:

Ryzen processors from AMD will certainly provide decent performance in Solidworks as well as Intel processors, and may in fact be faster due to the higher core count and larger cache.

Simply incorrect. SW, and basically all CAD programs, run single-threaded for a vast majority of their operations. Extra cores do very little to improve performance. The simple explanation is that you can’t calculate the results of extrude 286 while also calculating sketch 1, the computer has to start calculations at the top of the tree and go down, one feature at a time. This cannot be parallelized.

Some Ryzen CPUs are able to play with the big boys in single thread performance, but it is still dominated by Intel.

PassMark CPU Benchmarks - Single Thread Performance

image911×803 54.1 KB

At the end of the day if you’re happy with Ryzen integrated graphics, great. Keep using it. But it is not recommended by SW, any computer builders, or probably anyone who has done the sort of testing and benchmarking I have. Like I said, basically ANY GPU makes this problem go away for CAD. Even the T400 is rated for SW2025.

A lulzy tangent to this subject, and a big reason why I’ve done so much testing in this area, is that my day job sometimes looks like this:

image1056×835 45.2 KB

","post_number":11,"post_type":1,"posts_count":16,"updated_at":"2025-02-19T21:09:25.294Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":9,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":156,"readers_count":155,"score":136.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":492174,"topic_slug":"pc-specs-doubt","display_username":"JamesCH95","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.cpubenchmark.net/singleThread.html","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"PassMark CPU Benchmarks - Single Thread Performance","clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":6}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":3782,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/pc-specs-doubt/492174/11","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":6}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":6,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3533531,"name":"Nyx","username":"gellnick","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/gellnick/{size}/172273_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-19T21:47:00.135Z","cooked":"
JamesCH95:

Like I mentioned earlier, I have done this topic to death as part of my day job, and I just have to correct a lot of the misinformation in your reply.

I do not intend to say anything you have said is incorrect, if I implied that I apologize.

What I was trying to say, and probably should have said better, is that for many FIRST applications, Solidworks will run just fine on your integrated graphics chip. For more complex assemblies, yes a graphics card would be a good idea, but for many FIRST applications, it is simply not required. Source: I ran Solidworks on an integrated chip for pretty much my entire FRC career, and in general my laptop was running the full robot assembly without any issues, unless I was using too much RAM, which is a separate issue entirely.

I’m not sure how much the larger cache on many Ryzens would impact performance, but it certainly cannot hurt.

I’m gonna need to benchmark my own system, aren’t I?

","post_number":12,"post_type":1,"posts_count":16,"updated_at":"2025-02-19T21:47:00.135Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":11,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":120,"readers_count":119,"score":29.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":492174,"topic_slug":"pc-specs-doubt","display_username":"Nyx","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":29971,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Everything and nothing, all at the same time"},"post_url":"/t/pc-specs-doubt/492174/12","custom_user_title":"Everything and nothing, all at the same time","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3533955,"name":"JamesCH95","username":"JamesCH95","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/jamesch95/{size}/1200_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-20T06:06:18.666Z","cooked":"
gellnick:

I’m gonna need to benchmark my own system, aren’t I?

With and without your GPU installed would be ideal

Cache size and RAM go hand-in-hand, and are only important factors when working with large (real large) part and assembly files.

gellnick:

I do not intend to say anything you have said is incorrect, if I implied that I apologize.

I’m not mad at all for any disagreement, no need to apologize. I just want to be clear that integrated graphics are a bit of a letdown in CAD, and more cores won’t help.

Also worth checking if the integrated graphics are certified for SW. If not, then the risk of instability, crashes, and data loss goes way up.

","post_number":13,"post_type":1,"posts_count":16,"updated_at":"2025-02-20T06:06:18.666Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":12,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":105,"readers_count":104,"score":61.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":492174,"topic_slug":"pc-specs-doubt","display_username":"JamesCH95","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":3782,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/pc-specs-doubt/492174/13","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3533974,"name":"","username":"Alex_Y","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/a/82dd89/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-02-20T07:33:32.617Z","cooked":"
JamesCH95:

Some Ryzen CPUs are able to play with the big boys in single thread performance, but it is still dominated by Intel.

And how do we know that the passmark results aren’t intel biased or repetitive enough to solidworks to claim this? No benchmark is perfect and depending on the specific benchmark, the intel or AMD cpu can come out on top and its not super consistent which one comes out on top, at leas to the point where you can’t easily claim single-threaded performance is “dominated by Intel” anymore.

","post_number":14,"post_type":1,"posts_count":16,"updated_at":"2025-02-20T07:33:32.617Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":11,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":95,"readers_count":94,"score":29.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":492174,"topic_slug":"pc-specs-doubt","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":50219,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/pc-specs-doubt/492174/14","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3533992,"name":"JamesCH95","username":"JamesCH95","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/jamesch95/{size}/1200_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-20T10:31:34.582Z","cooked":"

This is part of my correlation between Passmark and SW RX results:

image1023×579 11.2 KB

Systems with GPUs, enough RAM, and a windows OS fall on a pretty clear line. The orange dot is the T15 w/o GPU.

Pugeot, Javelin, and Boxx all generally suggest the i7 or Core Ultra 7 now I guess, but I am seeing Ryzens starting to be suggested (this was not what I observed ~2 years ago).

SOLIDWORKS 2024 Hardware Recommendations

Hardware Recommendations for SOLIDWORKS | Puget Systems

The Ultimate SOLIDWORKS Workstation | BOXX Technologies

Noteworthy that Boxx is approximately equivocating Core Ultra 7 and Ryzen 9000 for entry-level CAD workstations.

Our conclusion, across multiple engineers/experts, was to use Intel Core/i CPUs for CAD and less-intensive FEA/modeling (single-thread performance is key), Intel Xeon for serious modeling (massive memory bandwidth), and Ryzen/Threadripper for image/vision processing (best parallelization across many cores).

Personally, I own Ryzen and Intel CPUs and CAD (for robots and for profit) with each. Ryzen can be just dandy, but Intel is a bit better.

","post_number":15,"post_type":1,"posts_count":16,"updated_at":"2025-02-20T10:31:34.582Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":14,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":3,"reads":96,"readers_count":95,"score":34.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":492174,"topic_slug":"pc-specs-doubt","display_username":"JamesCH95","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.pugetsystems.com/solutions/cad-workstations/solidworks/hardware-recommendations/","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Hardware Technologies","clicks":1}],"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":50219,"username":"Alex_Y","name":"","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/a/82dd89/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":3782,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/pc-specs-doubt/492174/15","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3533994,"name":"Ege Saygılı","username":"Crystolyte","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/crystolyte/{size}/233889_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-20T11:17:22.647Z","cooked":"

Over the years I have used Solidworks with integrated graphics(Intel HD Graphics, Iris Xe) , entry level mobile gaming graphics(Nvidia GTX 1050) and professional graphics(Quadro T2000), here is how I would rate them 10 being the absolute lightning smooth with the most complex assembly(the ratings assume adequate RAM (at least 16gb) and CPU performance).

  • Integrated : 4/10 (good for drawing parts, sketches, assemblies with low part counts, think like a subassembly of your robot)
  • Gaming : 7/10 (good enough for FRC in my book, can do everything integrated graphics can + bigger assemblies are better, if a higher end gaming graphics is considered, I would rate 8-9/10)
  • Professional : 9/10 (Solidworks runs best on these, I wouldn’t say they are a must have, I would recommend only if middle to long term usage for the card exists, going into college etc.)

I wouldn’t want to use Integrated graphics for any projects I am going pour hours into, emergency designs in a pinch however are OK.

When looking for comparisons between graphics cards regarding their Solidworks performance I try to compare NotebookCheck.net’s SPECviewperf Solidworks benchmark results for the respective cards I am comparing.

To add to my earlier post,
I’d prioritize getting as many interested students into CAD as possible way higher than getting the best possible performance. Shared computers at the build space don’t work very well in my experience because it severely limits time people can spend in CAD figuring things out and discourages playing around with non-team activities which are great for learning. Regardless of whether it’s the team, school or families buying the computers, you are unlikely to be able to afford new quadro powered workstations for everyone, every couple years. Between my personal computers and work computers I’ve had a lot of new laptops with the latest i7s and integrated graphics and a couple quadro workstations that had been getting passed around for 5+ years because they were too expensive to replace regularly. I much prefer to CAD with a really nice CPU and integrated graphics over a 5yo CPU with professional GPU. At my first job out of college I’d have to slow down sketching when I went from SolidWorks on my new windows tablet to my to the 5yo SolidWorks workstation at work, because the older computer was substantially slower and I’d end up clicking where something used to be. Most college and a lot of professional mechanical design never requires more complex assemblies than an FRC bot, so if you follow basic practices for keeping your models running quickly you will be fine with a less power computer. Do not model fasteners unless you need them for checking clearances, use natively modeled simplified versions of COTS components, etc. As a plus, the general purpose laptops tend to be lighter, have better battery life and generally be more practical as everyday carry laptops. So I recommend more basic laptops not because they have equal CAD performance but because they are fine for students and hobby work and students (or I) won’t delay buying a computer for 2 years because of the price tag.

I’ll run it on my igpu and my dgpu, I guess.
I’m fairly certain neither are certified for Solidworks since a “workstation” machine with similar specs would’ve cost roughly 2-3x as much while missing some of the little things I really appreciate while not really providing much benefit.
Which is kinda the point I was trying to get at - FRC use does not really need the fastest possible computer, instead something that works well is far preferable, even if it doesn’t have everything needed.

gellnick:

Which is kinda the point I was trying to get at - FRC use does not really need the fastest possible computer, instead something that works well is far preferable, even if it doesn’t have everything needed.

Let me explain my point differently…

A 7y/o workstation with a GPU vastly outperformed a brand new computer with integrated graphics. The older computer was 2x faster running SW despite using a CPU 33% slower.

You could go to eBay or whatever secondhand marketplace you like and buy an old workstation for pennies on the dollar with a GPU that will run SW better than a much newer computer running integrated graphics.
Or get a T400 GPU for $200
Or get a (pick an old GPU) for super cheap on eBay
Anything to get the heat and memory bandwidth of the graphics load out of the CPU.
